title: OpenCL & CUDA GPU support
body: It would be nice to have (relatively) easy access to the dedicated GPU's on our Win10 PC's, and OpenCL support for the AMD Drivers & CUDA for NVidia drivers etc.

comments.body: The main problem of using deep learning frameworks natively on Windows 10 is that the system always reserves 20% of the VRAM! In my case, I have a GTX1060 6GB, and I can only use 4.5 GB of VRAM to run my deep neural networks. These 1.5 GB are really useful when dealing with huge networks! In this case, it is better to keep using Linux where I can use all 6GB of VRAM. Apparently, Microsoft knows this, but have done nothing to improve the situation.

<sigh> Just as well I've been saving for a new B-I-Y(build it yourself) machine. I'll go ahead and install Debian on it and I have a nice Nvidia card with lots of cores on it to install for all my Gnu/Linux programming needs. I'll keep the Win machine for my ViStudio programming and game playing. With WSL2 being hyper-v  it's just not worth it to wait for gpu pass-thru, and they still haven't got raw sockets working either.

FYI y'all, Microsoft has no plans to do this for WSL. They think WSL 2 is the future and they will almost certainly do it there eventually. Meantime, they hope it will somehow become common for AI repos to work on regular windows.. looks like they will force Hyper-V. So it's unlikely they will achieve comparible GPU performance to native booted linux. So your repos will eventually work in a virtual machine (that can be pushed to Azure! haha) but nobody will really work that way since it will be slow. (but you can speed up in the cloud!! haha). Seems uservoice hit some deaf ears.
This is really needed as we are using intensivelly GPU for my work. Due to this limitation, I had to uninstall WIndows and install Unbuntu to run my projects.
People prefer to not dualboot.  For many, GPU support in WSL is why they still dualboot, and why they build machines without Windows to avoid dualboot.
+1 looking forward to use pytorch on WSL/WSL 2.
Please enable GPU support in Ubuntu from Windows 10 store! Thanks.
Great work on this so far! Working with TensorFlow and would love to enable some more features with GPU support. Chose Windows over alternatives for this dev, please support!
Working with TensorFlow and would love to enable some more features with GPU support. Chose Windows over alternatives for this dev, please support!
ust some basic GPU support like CUDA would be great as well...
Just some basic GPU support would be great as well...

I had in here a more detailed comment but for some reason it was deleted.
1) It is based on Hyper-V based on Microsoft's blogs (you can search "WSL 2 Hyper-V").
2) It seems that Virtualbox 6 can run with Hyper-V, so it may not longer be an issue?
That is something I need to know. Is it going to use Hyper-V? If it is that's going to make it rough on using some of the Python/Conda and other VM's out there that require Virtualbox. <sigh>

You'd think most of the pieces are now in place:
1) WSL 2 is now contained in Hyper-V VM
2) Windows (at least Server) supports Discrete Device Assignment (DDA) for GPU pass-through with Hyper-V
Now that WSL 2 has been announced and will run a full linux kernel, will this feature be possible? I couldn't find any information about presence or absence of GPU support in WSL 2.

To use Tensorflow and similar deep learning framework is a pain in Windows because most libraries / examples are generated and tested only for Linux.. to have this feature should be a great solution to continue to work with Windows.. otherwise the only solution should be to switch definitively on Linux
+1..looking forward for this

I asked for update on https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/3789 and they silenced it. I think the WSL team is doing great job addressing the huge number of incoming issues every day. But this might be too complicated for them to address so my guess is that we might not see any GPU support on WSL coming in the near future. I do hope I am wrong though.

This SHOULD NOT BE on the backlog. This should be implemented as soon as possible. This looks like it is the most requested feature of all. Every time I think of not installing Linux on a new machine I get, I come and check this and go install Linux anyway.

Rather a reason why Microsoft always looses its users as they never deliver on the most wanted thing and when competitors release the most wanted feature, they release a broken fix for the feature and then they start working on it. A classic Microsoft move which has them loose on so much market absolutely ridiculous and a clear move to miss out on the market opportunity
